citation.article-title: Isolation and physiological characterisation of Thiobacillus thyasiris sp. nov., a novel marine facultative autotroph and the putative symbiont of Thyasira flexuosa.

p.s: Description of Thiobacillus thyasiris sp. nov.
Thiobacillus thyasiris (thy.a.si'ris; M. L. adj. from Thyasira, a genus of the bivalve mollusc family of the Thyasiridae)

The description of T. thyasiris given here is based on the type strain (referred to as strain TG2 in this paper), deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Microorganismen, Braunschweig, FRG (DSM 5322).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporeforming, short rods 0.3 x 0.8-1.2 μm, and contain volutin and polyhydroxybutyrate inclusions.
There is no capsule but extracellular slime is variably produced during growth.
The organism is facultatively heterotrophic, able to grow on complex substrates such as yeast extract and on single carbon substrates including acetate and cellobiose.
It is autotrophic and chemolithotrophic, using the aerobic oxidation of sulphur, thiosulphate or tetrathionate for growth, during which the medium is lowered to a pH value of about pH 6.2.
Oxidizes sulphur, sulphide, thiosulphate, trithionate, tetrathionate and hexathionate, but not thiocyanate or dimethyl sulphide.
Cannot grow on formate or methylamine.
Grows anaerobically, with reduction of nitrate to nitrite and gas, on heterotrophic substrates but not thiosulphate.
Initiates growth over the range 10-45°C and pH 7.0-8.4.
Optimum pH 7.5; optimum temperature 35-40°C Moderately halophilic on thiosulphate medium and tolerating at least 3 M NaCl on acetate medium.
Carbon dioxide is fixed by means of ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase.
Colonies on thiosulphate agar are small (1 - 2 mm), circular, convex and smooth, becoming white with precipitated sulphur.
The DNA contains 52 mol % G + C.
Contains ubiquinone Q-10 as major quinone.
